title: Dick Butkus, Chicago Bears’ Fearsome Hall of Fame Linebacker, Dies at 80
description: He was both hard hitting against the run and fleet-footed in foiling pass plays in his eight seasons with the Chicago Bears. He later took up acting.

title: Will Voters Send In the Clowns?
description: Why would they think that a party that can’t manage itself can manage the economy?

title: Trump Said to Have Revealed Nuclear Submarine Secrets to Australian Businessman
description: Soon after leaving office, the former president shared sensitive information about American submarines with a billionaire member of Mar-a-Lago, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: If Moderate Republicans Were Brave, They Could Save the House
description: By cooperating with Democrats, they could elect one of their own as speaker.

title: Scalise and Jordan Seek House Speaker Backing as Trump Hangs Over Race
description: The two lawmakers sought support from members of their fractured party as the former president threatened to get involved in a potentially fierce struggle over who will lead the House.

title: Biden Is Expanding the Border Wall
description: Also, the Nobel Prize in Literature. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.

title: Opposition to Ukraine Aid Becomes a Litmus Test for the Right
description: The drama that has played out among House Republicans over the past week has highlighted a sharp decline in the party’s willingness to back continued aid for Kyiv’s fight against Russia.

title: Biden Watches House Republicans’ Dysfunction From a Distance
description: President Biden has chosen not to weigh in forcefully on the Republican meltdown in the House, instead trying to contrast his own achievements with the chaos of his rivals.

title: U.S. to Begin Deporting Venezuelans in Effort to Cut Down Border Numbers
description: The measure is the latest attempt by the Biden administration to try to reduce unlawful crossings at the southern border.

title: Syria Drone Attack Kills at Least 80, Government Says
description: Retaliatory shelling by Syrian government forces against towns in the northwest killed at least eight people, according to a rights group.

title: How MAGA Corrupts the Culture of the White Working Class
description: Republican elites are delivering the worst kind of red meat to their working-class base.

title: Trump Seeks Dismissal of Federal Election Case, Claiming Immunity
description: Donald Trump’s lawyers asked a judge to throw out charges that he conspired to overturn the 2020 election, arguing that a president could not be criminally prosecuted for official acts.

title: In Kevin McCarthy’s Hometown, Reflections on His Sudden Fall
description: Bakersfield, Calif., became more diverse and culturally expansive while the former House speaker was increasingly caught up in Washington’s barbed politics.

title: Pope Francis Warns on Climate Change
description: Naming and shaming the countries and industries he sees as bad actors.

title: Higher Rates Stoke a Growing Chorus of Deficit Concerns
description: A long period of higher interest rates would make the government’s large debt pile costly, a possibility that is fueling a conversation about debt sustainability.

title: Jon Fosse Receives Nobel Prize in Literature
description: Long a favorite to receive the award, Fosse has found acclaim for work that explores mortality and religion, and radiates serenity.

title: Armed Man Seeking Wisconsin Governor Posts Bail and Returns With Rifle
description: The man was taken into custody inside the State Capitol on Wednesday after asking to see Gov. Tony Evers, the authorities said. He posted bail and returned hours later with a rifle.

title: Alabama Is Ordered to Use Congressional Map That Likely Flips Seat to Democrats
description: The new voting map, chosen by a court after it ruled that Alabama illegally diluted Black voting power, could lead the state to elect two Black representatives for the first time in its history.

title: Why Trump and the Rest of the G.O.P. Won’t Stop Bashing Electric Vehicles
description: The industry’s transition to battery power is already underway. Republican presidential candidates are pushing to reverse course.

title: How the Big Chip Makers Are Pushing Back on Biden’s China Agenda
description: Nvidia, Intel and Qualcomm are campaigning to protect their businesses before further crackdowns on the sale of semiconductor technology to Beijing.

title: The Remaking of The Wall Street Journal
description: Emma Tucker, the top editor, is moving away from some of the organization’s traditions.

title: Biden Administration Waives Laws to Allow Expansion of Border Wall
description: The government cited the high numbers of migrants in the Rio Grande Valley in justifying the decision to waive a host of regulations.

title: Cornel West, Dropping Green Party, Will Run as an Independent
description: The left-wing scholar and writer has sought and then abandoned two third-party nominations since announcing his presidential campaign in June.

title: Hollywood Finally Figures Out What to Do With Nathan Lane
description: With roles in “Dicks: The Musical” and “Beau Is Afraid,” the stage star is now a regular for the hot film company A24. “Who would have guessed?” he says.

title: Trump Asks Again to Delay Documents Trial Until After Election
description: The former president’s lawyers said his trial on charges of mishandling classified information should be delayed from its planned start in May because of problems gaining access to all the evidence.

title: George Santos’s Accountant to Plead Guilty in Federal Inquiry
description: Nancy Marks, one of the embattled congressman’s closest associates, oversaw the campaign finances that have faced widespread scrutiny.

title: Women Could Fill Truck Driver Jobs. Companies Won’t Let Them.
description: Three women filed a discrimination complaint against a trucking company over its same-sex training policy, which they say prevented them from being hired.

title: A Giacometti for a Cezanne: Jeffrey Epstein’s Role in a Pricey Art Deal
description: Mr. Epstein helped the billionaire Leon Black defer capital gains taxes from the swap. A Senate committee is scrutinizing some of Mr. Black’s art deals as it looks into tax avoidance schemes.

title: Who is Jon Fosse?
How to Choose the Nobel Laureate: Tap a Literature Professor
description: The Swedish Academy sends out thousands of invitations each year for professors and others in the literary world to nominate writers for the prize in a secretive and precise process.

title: America’s Political Turmoil
description: A survey of the chaos across the U.S. political system.

title: How to Choose the Nobel Laureate: Tap an English Professor
description: The Swedish Academy sends out thousands of invitations each year for professors and others in the literary world to nominate writers for the prize in a secretive and precise process.

title: The Mosquitoes Are Winning
description: The rapid evolution of the insect has helped drive up Malaria deaths in Africa, fueling a growing public health threat.

title: Today’s Top News: Secretary Blinken Travels to Mexico, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.

title: Diesel Prices Could Keep Inflation High
description: The cost of the fuel has been rising in recent weeks and could spike this winter because of supply problems, analysts warn.

title: Americans Are Losing Faith in U.S. Democracy as Far Right Revolts
description: Amid upheaval on Capitol Hill and the undermining of democratic norms, the country’s institutions are under profound stress.

title: New Testimony in Tupac Murder Case Describes What Led to Fatal Shooting
description: Grand jury witness testimony describes how hyperlocal clashes between warring gang factions spilled into a fatal dispute that would alter the course of hip-hop history.

title: Testimony in Tupac Shakur Murder Case Gives New Details
description: Grand jury witness testimony describes how hyperlocal clashes between warring gang factions spilled into a fatal dispute that would alter the course of hip-hop history.

title: The Kaiser Strike Is Only Part of What’s Ailing U.S. Health Care
description: Health care policymakers and industry leaders must reckon with the difficulties facing workers if we want to avert strikes.

title: An Overdue Lesson on Antiracism
description: Ibram X. Kendi became a national arbiter on race, even though his reductionist approach was at odds with principles of free inquiry and expression.

title: Jack Fisk: The Genius Behind Hollywood’s Most Indelible Sets
description: How Jack Fisk, the master production designer behind ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’ and many other films, brings the past to life.

title: Wildfires, Flooding, Heat: How Climate Changed Upended Summer
description: The globe’s warmest months on record redefined summer for many Americans.

title: A Start-Up’s Alternative to Uber: Employing Its Own Drivers
description: Alto is trying to fill a more expensive niche, especially as politicians and labor groups argue that the contractor model exploits drivers.

title: The Wegovy Shortage Drags On, Leaving Patients in Limbo
description: The situation has left many patients frustrated and unable to start taking the weight loss drug.

title: On the Streets of Paris Fashion Week, a Warm Embrace of Color
description: During Paris Fashion Week, almost every color could be spotted on the streets and the runways.

title: Was New York City Unprepared to Handle Last Week’s Extreme Rainfall?
description: The city comptroller and the City Council will launch separate inquiries into the city’s preparation for the storm.

title: New U.A.W. Chief Has a Nonnegotiable Demand: Eat the Rich
description: Shawn Fain’s disdain for the “billionaire class” informs his showdown with Detroit’s automakers. Now he must prove that his hard-core tactics pay off.

title: The Brooklyn Subway Shooter Faces Sentencing on 10 Terrorism Counts
description: Prosecutors asked a judge to give Frank James 10 life sentences, one for each victim wounded in the April 2022 shooting aboard an N train in Brooklyn.

title: Workers Exposed to Extreme Heat Have Few Protections
description: Tens of millions of Americans are struggling to cope with soaring temperatures. OSHA is developing new workplace safety standards, but they are not yet complete.

title: Nio Loses $35,000 a Car. That Should Scare the U.S. and Europe.
description: Chinese electric vehicle companies like Nio are pulling ever further ahead, partly through government support but also rapid technological advances.

title: Bidens’ Dog Commander Is Removed From White House After Latest Biting Incident
description: Commander, a 2-year-old German shepherd, bit a Secret Service officer last week, the 11th incident involving “aggressive behavior” by the president’s pets.

title: Gun Deaths Rising Sharply Among Children, Study Finds
description: Firearm injuries are a leading cause of death among young children and teenagers in the United States.

title: Holyoke Shooting Leaves Baby Dead and Mother Injured
description: Shots were fired during a dispute involving three men in Holyoke, Mass., on Wednesday afternoon, the authorities said. The suspects were taken to hospitals and are in custody.

title: Trump Announces $45.5 Million Fund-Raising Haul, Tripling DeSantis
description: The Trump campaign’s total, which cannot be independently verified until later this month, was built in part by an outpouring of money after his mug shot in Georgia was released.

title: Food Industry Influence Could Cloud the U.S. Dietary Guidelines, a New Report Says
description: The process of updating the healthy eating recommendations has become more transparent in recent years, but conflicts persist.
